_header: Little child sithen your tender infancy
Subjects: children, instructions for behavior of; manners, treatises on; courtesy books; instruction
_description: ‘The Book of Courtesy’ — seventy-six stanzas rhyme royal

OxfBal354.First Lines:
Lytell Iohn sith your tender enfancyeSondyth as yet vnder
                    Indyfference…
OxfBal354.Last Lines:
…& how to hurte lyeth ever in a wayteKepe your quayre
                    þat yt be not ther bayte
OxfBal354.Note:
Transcript from 
            [Explicit the book of curtesye], [Westminster: By William Caxton, 1477-1478] .
OxfBal354.Attributed Title:
Here begynnyth lytill Iohn (p. 341); Here endyth a lytyll treatyse called
                    þe boke of curtesy or litill Iohn (p. 351)
OxfBal354.Facsimiles:
Early Manuscripts at Oxford University: Facsimile
                    of Oxford, Balliol MS 354.
         (http://image.ox.ac.uk/show?collection=balliol&manuscript=ms354).
OxfBal354.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Caxton’s Book of Curtesye.
EETS
         e.s. 3 (1868); repr. 1973.
